Award.AwardTitle: TWC: TTP Option: Medium: Collaborative: MALDIVES: Developing a Comprehensive Understanding of Malware Delivery Mechanisms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cybercriminal community is inarguably more organized, better resourced and more motivated than ever to perpetrate massive-scale computer infections across the Internet. The malware distribution systems that they control and operate are characterized by their use of highly specialized suppliers and commoditized malware services. As a consequence of this development, criminals with little technical expertise can deploy and administer sophisticated exploit kits, and instantiate malicious-content advertising (malvertising) campaigns that surreptitiously infect hundreds of thousands of innocent victims. The MALDIVES project is developing a new generation of technologies to provide deeper insights into how these malware distribution systems are deployed, operated, and interlinked with open web sources.

The MALDIVES project is organized as a sequence of five attack observation lablets (ATOLLs) which are collectively designed to acquire an in-depth understanding of the key stages in contemporary malware dissemination infrastructures. The Platform Acquisition Observatory (PLATO) is focused on studying the deployment phase of the server-side infection infrastructures. This observatory extends web-application-vulnerability mimicry systems with a dynamic exploit-kit interrogation system, and adds automated intelligence tools to understand subsequent victim infection strategies. The Victim Enticement Scheme Evaluation Lablet (VESSEL) is focused on studying the targeting phase of the malware infection lifecycle. It develops tools and conducts measurements on various enticement schemes, such as Search Engine Optimization (SEO) poisoning and malvertising. The Traffic Redirection Observation Lablet (TROLL) is focused on the delivery phase and builds active and passive techniques to measure malware-related traffic redirection chains. The Exploit Kit Interrogation Environment (EXPLORE) builds automated probes to facilitate the detection and measurement of professionally designed automated infection services. The Defensive Strategies Investigation Lablet (DISTILL) investigates novel malware-defense capabilities based on the insights acquired from prior lablets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
final report and something else (search email)

The key goal of the project is to improve our understanding of contemporary malware delivery mechanisms through the development of new technologies and analytics to study how malware infection infrastructures are deployed, operated, and then interlinked with open web sources to target victims.  The project is organized into five lablets: platform observation laboratory (PLATO), victim enticement laboratory (VESSEL), traffic redirection observation laboratory (TROLL), exploit kit interrogation environment (EXPLORE) and defensive strategies investigation laboratory (DISTILL).

The project produced more than eight peer-reviewed publications in flagship venues, which reported our research findings to the public and advanced the knowledge and understanding about contemporary malware delivery mechanisms. For example, one publication studied the malware trends in enterprise networks, offering insights on preventing and detecting malware targeting enterprises. Another publication reported our experience and knowledge learned from investigating advanced persistant threats (APT) and cybercrime toolkits, which filled the void in understanding how these offensive activities work and evolve.

The project developed novel analysis techniques to track the delivery and infection patterns of contemporary malware. It produced the first automated infrastructure for harvesting, analyzing, and detecting malvertisements on mobile devices. It produced a data analysis framework for enabling better understanding of ransomware distribution and operation. It produced analysis and detection engine for multiple families of exploit kits. It produced an analysis and detection engine for HTTP conversation graphs that involve malware infection. It also produced analytics for automated classification of dark web intelligence. The container security work produced by the project is being transitioned to a startup.

The project also provided education and training oppertunities to numerous students from more than five US universities and institutions. In particular, graduate students and postdoctoral associates directly participated in the project, developed their degree thesis based on the research, and contributed significantly to the findings.


Last Modified: 10/23/2020
Modified by: Long Lu
